Title:
Phylogenetics of the Chamaesyce clade (Euphorbia,
Euphorbiaceae): Reticulate evolution and long-distance dispersal in a
prominent C4 lineage
Keywords:
C4 photosynthesis; Chamaesyce; Euphorbia; Hawaiian
Islands; long-distance dispersal; low-copy nuclear marker; reticulate
evolution; short chloroplast genome inversion; weeds.
Abstract:
Â• Premise of the study: The Chamaesyce clade of Euphorbia
is the largest lineage of C4 plants among the eudicots, with 350 species
including both narrow endemics and cosmopolitan weeds. We sampled this
group worldwide to address questions about subclade relationships, the
origin of C4 photosynthesis, the evolution of weeds, and the role of
hybridization and long-distance dispersal in the diversification of the
group.
